title: Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST)
description: Identifies patients who are malnourished or at risk of malnutrition using BMI, weight loss, and acute disease effects

parameters.name: weight_loss_percentage
parameters.description: Unplanned weight loss in the past 3-6 months as percentage of body weight

parameters.name: acute_disease_effect
parameters.description: Patient acutely ill with no nutritional intake for >5 days or likely to have no intake for >5 days

result.name: must_score
result.description: MUST total score and malnutrition risk level

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of malnutrition. Routine clinical care with repeat screening in hospital weekly, in care homes monthly, and in community annually for special groups.

Medium risk of malnutrition. Document dietary intake and observe for 3 days. If improved intake - little clinical concern. If no improvement, follow clinical guidelines. Repeat screening in hospital weekly and in care homes/community monthly.

High risk of malnutrition. Refer to dietitian, nutritional support team or implement local policy. Improve and increase overall nutritional intake. Monitor and review care plan regularly. Repeat screening in hospital weekly and in care homes/community monthly.

references: Elia M. The 'MUST' report. Nutritional screening of adults: a multidisciplinary responsibility. Redditch: BAPEN; 2003.
Kondrup J, Allison SP, Elia M, Vellas B, Plauth M. ESPEN guidelines for nutrition screening 2002. Clin Nutr. 2003 Aug;22(4):415-21.

Stratton RJ, Hackston A, Longmore D, Dixon R, Price S, Stroud M, et al. Malnutrition in hospital outpatients and inpatients: prevalence, concurrent validity and ease of use of the 'malnutrition universal screening tool' ('MUST') for adults. Br J Nutr. 2004 Nov;92(5):799-808.
formula: BMI score (≥20: 0pts, 18.5-20: 1pt, <18.5: 2pts) + Weight loss score (<5%: 0pts, 5-10%: 1pt, >10%: 2pts) + Acute disease effect (no: 0pts, yes: 2pts)
notes: Developed by BAPEN (British Association for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition) in 2003
Widely used screening tool in UK healthcare settings
Suitable for use in hospitals, care homes, and community settings
Can detect both under-nutrition and over-nutrition
Linked to evidence-based care plans and treatment pathways
Should be repeated regularly: weekly in hospitals, monthly in care homes/community
Requires clinical judgment for interpretation in specific populations
Consider alternative measurements if BMI cannot be calculated
Document food intake when medium or high risk identified
Early intervention more effective than treatment of established malnutrition
